content: Is Atlantis actually a planet on the other side of the sun?
reply: Is Atlantis actually a planet on the other side of the sun?
title: Atlantis, a planet?

content: Don't think so. It's theoretically possible that there might be a plant that is exactly opposite the Earth, with the same orbital path (180 degrees out of phase), and the same orbital period.... but we have probes go above the solar ecliptic, and so we would have discovered if there was a planet exactly opposite us.
reply: Don't think so. content: My theory on Atlantis is that earth was called Atlantis before the great flood. It never really disappeared, previous civilization wiped out, replaced by our civilization. Is this legal? I don't know,but its fun isn't?!
reply: My theory on Atlantis is that earth was called Atlantis before the great flood. It never really disappeared, previous civilization wiped out, replaced by our civilization. Is this legal? I don't know,but its fun isn't?!

content: quote: Originally posted by DSTremf: My theory on Atlantis is that earth was called Atlantis before the great flood. It never really disappeared, previous civilization wiped out, replaced by our civilization. You should read E.E. Smith's (aka Doc Smith) Lensmen Series. The first novel of the series Tri-Planetary discusses a similar Atlantis distruction and the rise of our Civilization. FYI - Doc Smith is considered the creator of the "Space Opera". George Lucas borrowed from him quite liberally. My Father met his daughter at a teaching convention when I was in Junior High. Dad knew I was a Sci-Fi junkie and told her as much, she gave him, for me, a near complete set of her father's works a "new" re-printing from that time (mid 1980s). Still have them today, they're a great read.
quote: Originally posted by DSTremf: My theory on Atlantis is that earth was called Atlantis before the great flood. It never really disappeared, previous civilization wiped out, replaced by our civilization.

content: I have a question. Each stone on one of the pyrmaids weighs 200 tons. Only 2 machines exist in the world that can lift that kind of weight. How did the ancient Egyptians accomplish this? But, here is the question. Whoever determined the exact weight of the stone, how did that person manage to weigh the stone, if it cannot be moved?
